title: Cleethorpes Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Richard Croft / Cleethorpes Country Park
images.caption: This stone commemorates the formal designation of Cleethorpes Country Park as a Local Nature Reserve, as unveiled by The Mayor of the Borough of North East Lincolnshire Councillor Colin Eastwell for an on behalf of the Citizens of North East Lincolnshire on this day

images.title: Richard Croft / Lakeside
images.caption: Lakeside. A wide range of waterfowl on the lake by the Discovery Centre at Cleethorpes

description: This 160 acre park has a 7 acre lake with footpaths and a cycle path running through it. It's also a designated nature reserve with lots of interesting flora and fauna. Look out for various wildflowers and birdlife including wildfowl on the lake and skylarks in the air. The park is located near to Cleethorpes town centre and the sea front so you could continue your walk or ride along the coast. Just east is the Cleethorpes nature reserve with a discovery centre and a pretty lake next to the coast.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The park is great for dog walking and there's even a designated dog swimming area for them to paddle around in. The nearby Weelsby Woods mentioned below is another popular spot for dog walkers.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your walking in the area head south and try the Cleethorpes to Tetney Lock Walk. The walk takes you along the Tetney Marshes RSPB nature reserve to the pretty lock on the Louth Canal. Also nearby is Weelsby Woods. This popular park has some nice surfaced footpaths taking you to mature trees, woodland, and large grassy areas. The Grimsby Walk starts from the train station in the town and visits the interesting National Fishing Heritage Centre at Alexandra Dock. The museum transports you back in time to the 1950’s heyday of this famous port. If you head a few miles inland you could pick up the Wanderlust Way around the little village of Barnoldby le Beck. The 20 mile circular walk explores the Lincolnshire Wolds and includes views of the Humber Estuary. For more walking ideas in the area see the Lincolnshire Walks page.
